column4: with openoffice, what's the difference between using the java runtime environment and not using it?
5 minutes in loading time? :)
as in disabling it will make it load faster or slower?
bursts? that's weird
I read somewhere that it does it to preserve write cycles?
err, not sure. i mean, it will certainly try and write several blocks at a time, but why would it stop between one and the other? (i guess that's what "bursts" means)
that's what I'm wondering, too...but that's what it seems to be doing, at least when writing to this external hard drive I have. it doesn't seem to be as apparent with my USB drive, though
maybe it's just the *source* it's copying data *from* that's slower than the destination?
I don't think so. it happens whether I'm copying from my USB drive (like right now) or from my computer's hard drive
your internal HD might be slower than your external - especially if the files you're copying are fragmented all over the drive
try doing a test copy from, say, /dev/zero
see if that's done in bursts too
/dev/zero? I'm not sure what you mean
/dev/zero is a "virtual" device that just generates zeroes, as many as you want (until you stop it), and as quickly possible
if you cp /dev/zero to /mnt/whatever (perhaps use "time" to see how long it takes too), you should see just how the external drive is doing unrelated to the drive you're copying from
as normal - cp /dev/zero <destinationfile>. just ctrl+c it when you think you've had enough of it.
you definitely should
do it when your computer is as idle as possible

I did what you said, but I'm not sure what to look for. the file appaears, but I have no way to guage the progress. normallly the "copying files" window pops up, and that's how I know it does things in bursts
i thought you could look at the HD icon. well, i guess you could always try navigating to /dev/ in Nautilus, and then copying "zero" from there. not sure whether that works.

on a related note, when I stopped copying from /dev/zero and chose to delete the file I had made, it took about 10 seconds for it to get around to deleting it...even though it was only about 142 MB, and then it deleted it in a flash
copying /dev/zero through Nautilus did indeed bring up the "Copying Files" window, and it went FAST
